statement.p:
Find the Laplace transform of each of the following functions.
t e^{-2t}
\sin at
\cos at
e^{at} \sin bt
If f is a piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded function defined [0, \infty), prove that the Laplace transform of f, {\mathcal L}(f)(s)= F(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} f(t) \, dt exists.

ol.li: Let y = y(t) and y'(t) be piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded functions and assume that y'' is exponentially bounded. Prove that {\mathcal L}(y'')(s) = s^2 {\mathcal L}(y)(s) - sy(0) - y'(0)= s^2 Y(s) - sy(0) - y'(0) for large values of s, where Y(s) is the Laplace transform of y.

If y = y(t) and all of its derivatives up to order k - 1 are piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded functions and y^{(k)} is piecewise continuous, prove that
{\mathcal L}(y^{(k)})(s) = s^k {\mathcal L}(y)(s) - s^{k - 1}y(0) - \cdots - s y^{(k -2)}(0) - y^{(k -1)}(0) = s^k Y(s) - s^{k - 1}y(0) - s^{k - 1}y(0)- \cdots - s y^{(k -2)}(0) - y^{(k -1)}(0).

statement.p:
Define the gamma function to be \Gamma(x) = \int_0^\infty e^{-t} t^{x-1} \; dt.
Show that \Gamma(1) = 1.
Prove that \Gamma(x + 1) = x\Gamma(x) and deduce that \Gamma(n+1) = n! for n \in {\mathbb N}.
Show that the Laplace transform of f(t) = t^\alpha is {\mathcal L}(f)(s) = \frac{\Gamma(\alpha + 1)}{s^{\alpha + 1}}. If n is a positive integer, then {\mathcal L}(t^n)(s) = n!/s^{n + 1}.
